Linq for NHibernate is released

Posted by Jeremy Miller on July 26, 2009

I’ll let you go read Ayende’s post on Linq for NHibernate.  Team Dovetail has been using it for over a year without any problems — but we don’t do crazy data centric reporting and projections type work.

 

The official release announcement is here.

About Jeremy Miller

Jeremy is the Chief Software Architect at Dovetail Software, the coolest ISV in Austin. Jeremy began his IT career writing "Shadow IT" applications to automate his engineering documentation, then wandered into software development because it looked like more fun. Jeremy is the author of the open source StructureMap tool for Dependency Injection with .Net, StoryTeller for supercharged acceptance testing in .Net, and one of the principal developers behind FubuMVC. Jeremy's thoughts on all things software can be found at The Shade Tree Developer at http://codebetter.com/jeremymiller.

The TFS MVP Kerfluffle →
  • http://www.blogcoward.com jdn

    How do you use it?

  • http://codebetter.com/members/jmiller/default.aspx Jeremy D. Miller

    @jdn,

    Mostly simple “find this entity where property1 == this value.” The only halfway fancy thing we do is server side paging and that works just fine. We don’t have any significant reporting that uses it, but then again, why would you do reporting with NH anyway?

    Most of our business logic only involves a transaction against one or a few entities at a time, so we just don’t need all that wacky subquery stuff. We do go straight at ICriteria for the handful of projections we need, but I think that would work with Linq for NH.

    Ok, I’m counting down from 10 until the next time I see you calling me names somewhere else on the ‘net.

  • http://www.blogcoward.com jdn

    Ok, I’m thinking of using it on a spike project, so it sounds like there aren’t any significant gotchas. Use it like you might use LINQ to Objects.

    Have I called you names on the net? Maybe that one blog post that one time, but there was a reason for that, if you recall. I think.

    Like the Event Aggregator (almost called it Event Aggravator for some reason…LOL) stuff as well, it does a useful job of listing out the different options one could take and the reasons why you chose the ones you did. Perfect timing for me as I want to spike out something with that as well to see if I can make it more central.

    Thanks.

  • Konstantin

    Hello! I catch the NullReference exception by this test:
    ==========================================================================================
    [Test]
    public void Should_Get_By_Dictionary_Value()
    {
    using (ISession s = NHibernateHelper.GetCurrentSession())
    {
    var queryable = s.Linq();
    var first = queryable.First( a => a.Items["first"].Name == “first b”);
    Assert.That(first, Is.Not.Null);
    }
    }
    ==========================================================================================
    But this Ok:
    ==========================================================================================
    [Test, Description("Должен получать по значению метаданного")]
    public void Should_Get_By_Dict_Value()
    {
    using (ISession s = NHibernateHelper.GetCurrentSession())
    {
    var queryable = s.Linq    ();
    var list = queryable.ToList();
    var first = list.First(a => a.Items["first"].Name == “first b”);
    Assert.That(first, Is.Not.Null);
    }
    }
    ==========================================================================================
    I think that NHimbernate.Linq don’t support lazy loading…..
    Implementation of class A, mappings and test:
    ==========================================================================================
    public class A
    {
    private int? _id;
    private string _name;
    private IDictionary _items;

    public A() { }

    public int? Id
    {
    get { return _id; }
    set { _id = value; }
    }

    public string Name
    {
    get { return _name; }
    set { _name = value; }
    }

    public IDictionary Items
    {
    get { return _items; }
    set { _items = value; }
    }
    }

    public class B
    {
    private int? _id;
    private string _name;

    public B() { }

    public int? Id
    {
    get { return _id; }
    set { _id = value; }
    }

    public string Name
    {
    get { return _name; }
    set { _name = value; }
    }
    }
    ===========================================================================================
    < ?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8" ?>







    ===========================================================================================
    [Test]
    public void AB()
    {
    A a = new A();
    a.Name = “first generic type”;
    a.Items = new Dictionary();
    B firstB = new B();
    firstB.Name = “first b”;
    B secondB = new B();
    secondB.Name = “second b”;

    a.Items.Add(“first”, firstB);
    a.Items.Add(“second”, secondB);

    using (ISession s = NHibernateHelper.GetCurrentSession())
    {
    s.SaveOrUpdate(a);
    s.Flush();

    Assert.IsNotNull(a.Id);
    Assert.IsNotNull(firstB.Id);
    Assert.IsNotNull(secondB.Id);

    var query = from v in s.Linq()
    where v.Id == a.Id
    select v;

    a = query.FirstOrDefault();
    B thirdB = new B();
    thirdB.Name = “third B”;
    a.Items.Add(“third”, thirdB);
    Assert.AreEqual(3, a.Items.Count, “3 items in the map now”);
    s.Flush();

    a = s.Load(a.Id);
    a.Items["second"] = a.Items["third"];
    s.Flush();
    }
    }

  • http://devlicio.us/blogs/tuna_toksoz Tuna Toksoz

    No, not a lazy loading issue.
    The problem is likely that we haven’t implemented map stuff. Can you do that in criteria api? how? If you can find the answer, then it can be implemented with Linq.
